Throughout the entirety of the jungle animals of all sorts could be
seen an=
d heard, some flitting here and there in the trees, or the
shadow of moveme=
nt just seen out of the corner of the optic. For those
with enhanced senses=
 this place was teeming with all sorts of life
from the large to the small.=
 However one thing would make itself
abundantly clear to cybertronians almo=
st immediately. All
communications appeared to be out. All tracking beacons=
, com-links and
signals had been cut off. For those inside the jungle there=
 was no
communication at all with the outside, and to those outside the jun=
gle
it was as if TUSCON and WHEELIE had just disappeared.

However, interes=
tingly enough, the sensors of anyone with even a
modicum of detection gear =
should be able to pick up a low level 'hum'
of strange energy that suffused=
 the entire area. Not a force field but
just an energy wave that was in the=
 background of things. To those who
were familiar with it, the =91hum=92 ha=
d a Unicronian signature to it

> <OLD - WHEELIE>
>
> Not having a more exp=
licit idea fo what was going on, Wheelie gingerly
> continued, one step at =
a time, going slowly and warily.  Keeping his energon
> slingshot in a subs=
pace pocket but fully charged, so should it come over to
> combat he could =
immediately whip it out to engage someone, and keeping
> enough space betwe=
en himself and the underbrush if he was ambushed he would
> have some room =
to react.

<NEW - Wheelie>

The trek that WHEELIE is on has brought him out=
 into more open areas
of the jungle. The canopy of trees has grown unusuall=
y thick meaning
that the underbrush has died back, leaving the floor of the=
 jungle,
while uneven, relatively clear of plant life. The area is dark, bu=
t
not overly so, much like a day in the open as the sun was setting, or
per=
haps behind dense storm clouds.

The silence around WHEELIE was becoming mo=
re pronounced as he moved
forward. He could see signs that larger animals h=
ad indeed moved
through the area. The bark had been knocked off or actual d=
ents or
cuts made in the trees themselves.

Twin optics appeared glowing fr=
om the shadows but strangely enough
WHEELIE is unable to lock on it with an=
y sort of sensors.

> <OLD - TUSCON>
>
> As he nears a large tree, his outs=
tretched arms allow him to catch a giant
> branch with both hands as he swi=
ngs off it like a skilled gymnast .  After a
> spin or two, to build his mo=
mentum, he vaults to a lower branch and
> continues to do so until he final=
ly touches down for a flawless landing as
> he uses his arms for balance.  =
Leaf litter falls in his wake as he first
> looks around to get his bearing=
s.

<NEW>

As TUSCON landed on the jungle floor high over head a flock of b=
irds
at the top of the canopy of trees rose into the air obviously startled=

by his passing, the sound of their calls filling the air for a moment.
How=
ever soon enough the birds flew off to find new places to roost and
to find=
 food.

The ground that TUSCON has landed is still relatively open, but he =
can
easily make out the path leading further into the jungle where the
tree=
s and undergrowth would make travel more difficult for anyone.
Large trees =
surround him on all sides. Many of them had been knocked
down by large anim=
als of some sort, but the evidence of this
destruction became less and less=
 the further in he looked.

Enhanced senses could easily make out the pleth=
ora of life that lived
in the jungle as animals and birds of all shapes and=
 sizes made their
home in the miles and miles of this wooded area. However =
his enhanced
senses could also pick up the movement of something else, that=
 moved
out in the brush ahead of him. However his sensors were unable to pi=
ck
up on it. He could see a figure ahead that looked vaguely humanoid in
th=
e distance, although with the brush and foliage between him and them
it was=
 difficult to distinguish size and configuration.
